Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: I gained economic skils, but as a student coming from a developing country I don't feel I gained any valuable skills to implement back in my country where challenges in the social and economic arena are very complex.

This class is great for understanding different kinds of energy and how to go about thinking which are more appropriate in different contexts. I appreciated learning more and understanding global considerations regarding carbon emissions, climate change, and energy debates (including those about oil, wind, solar).
Received a more in depth understanding of how policy-makers leverage (or don't leverage) current research.
Understanding of the economics that underlie the electricity industry, the market failures that can occur, and the policies that can be used to address these failures.
Deep understanding of energy economics and policy analysis.
Learnt a lot about energy, energy policy and energy economics

So many different skills - whether it's understanding energy economics through the policy framework, engaging with new and innovative policies, or just hearing from Ken's background. It was a broad and deep class. Definitely geared towards advanced students, which I liked.

This course exposed me to various facets of energy, their underlying economics and the role of policy in each of them. 
The resources/papers were excellent and were balanced in the sense that for any given policy analysis, different perspectives were placed for our understanding. That helped me learn both sides of an argument coherently. 
As a student of economics, it was wonderful to apply basic concepts to the most complex energy issues! 
Apart from the excellent in-class learnings, it was great to work on a group project. The project enabled me to improve my technical skills, exposed me to the energy sector of Pakistan and made me aware of challenges in energy, especially in the context of a developing country. 

Overall, Professors  teaching, class discussions, the materials and problem sets very very comprehensive for a one-semester course. 

My best takeaways from the semester have been from this class!
Good general understanding of important topics in Energy Economics, and application of economic models to policy.
I gained insight into how economists view energy markets and policies, which was enlightening.
Comprehensive overview of topics related to energy markets and economics; introduction to the preeminent energy economics authors and ongoing debates

This course covers the core economic principles that apply to energy and environmental policy and allows students to both study the more qualitative policy approaches and the more quantitative economic analysis of, mostly US, environmental and energy policy.
How to better analyze different energy policy options for a sustainable future.
Pretty wide-ranging knowledge. I think the syllabus tells much of the story, but I'll also add that it's a nice mix of law/policy.

So much! Oil markets, carbon mitigation schemes, renewable energy policy, energy market structuring. It was superb! The interagency working group history and the social cost of carbon metrics were really really cool and extremely important.

A comprehensive overview of energy-related policies in oil, gas, the electricity market, renewable energy, and transportation, from an economic perspective. Topics including (but not limited to) oil prices, the law of one price (oil vs natural gas), electricity deregulation (California electricity crisis discussed), RPS and FIT, pollution externalities and abatement policies (tradeable permit, price rule vs. quantity rule), energy efficiency policies, and transportation-related incentives were covered.
energy and electricity markets; externalities; renewable energy technologies, investment, and policy; energy efficiency policy; transportation policy.
I was able to build upon my previous experience of energy economics. The class provided information on recent trend in energy stuff as well.
I have a much deeper understanding on how, and why energy systems behave the way they do.
Overview of how climate and environmental issues play out through policy mechanisms.
They did not align at all with my expectations.
Very well
Pretty well, though the class did go into the weeds a little more than I had hoped. But good class overall!
Very well
Exceeded expectations!
Really well
Yep, they did. I heard a lot of good things about the course and it really exceeded my expectations!

Very well. The class was beyond what I had expected. Since the group project in this course was a major part of the grade, I expected the in-class learnings to be proportional. But the learnings from the class have been beyond what I had expected. They were very informational, insightful and rigorous too! 

Being a student of a one year masters program, I was looking for something rigorous and interesting at the same time. This course was a great choice!
Pretty well
This class met my expectations in terms of what I learned from it.
Very well

This class exceeded my expectations. I felt that each component of the course was really well though out a engaging. No part of this course felt like busy work and I truly learned so much! I feel much more confident about my ability to think about energy policy through an economic lens after taking this course.
Very well.
Quite nicely. I think it's as advertised.

Great - we covered a lot more than I thought we would and looked at things from all angles... not just environmental ones which is important. The intricacies of oil markets and contending theories about an integrated oil market vs the need for oil security premiums is a relevant dialogue that was unknown to me.
Extremely well.
They aligned very well. I was pleased with what I gained from this course.
The class homework was interesting in understanding many energy-related issues from policy perspective.
Exceeded expectations

The strenghs are the project. The weaknesses relay on the fact that we do not cover any energy poverty, environmental justice, or social inequality topics, which can't be at all avoid when teaching energy economics. This was very disappointing.
Very interesting class covering a range of topics in energy
I liked it; I would have appreciated a little more discussion about the political economy of energy and political considerations in general, and not just policy implications.

This course covers a wide breadth of topics, but touches on topics that many students already had familiarity with. Thought the homework sets were very well developed to maximize applied learning. However, the course relies on material that seems like it was last updated 5 years ago. In a time of rapidly changing energy policy, would have been great to have some more discussion on what is the most effective way of developing and deploying new energy policy. Covering fewer topics in more depth would have been great.

Very academic focused, which is great considering Nordhauss contemporaneous award. Would have appreciated some more practical perspectives, e.g., is a world carbon price/tax really politically feasible? If not, what policy mechanisms might work better?
Great course, lots of material covered. Ken is a legend.

Great overview of a lot of relevant topics related to energy economics. 
strong focus on the US, no examples of international policies/challenges regarding energy.
Not much to say in terms of improving it? I guess focusing on some of these topics more or changing into a 2 semester class could allow certain ideas to be discovered more deeply.

Strengths of the course: Professors insights, the course materials and problem sets. 

Aspects that can be improved: I would love to have done more problem sets! 
Another aspect would be that the technical parts of a paper could be elaborated upon a little more in class. I am sure that Professor has kept in mind the technical background  of students, but personally, I would have preferred to have done some more problem solving in class!
I liked the problem sets - they were at a good level to promote understanding.

Strengths: Lectures, readings (it was really helpful being informed which readings we should read carefully/skim and which were optional), project

Weaknesses: I didn't feel the exam was a good measure of our learning since it only covered a few concepts. I think something like a longer, take-home exam that was broader would be an improvement.
I thought the course was super well done and would recommend it in its current format.

I think the structure of the course is designed really well. I thought the reading supplemented the class discussions very well and found the problem set and term paper to fill out the quantitative needs of the class. I am not sure that a mid-term exam is necessary in this class-given the problem sets  and final paper and presentations but understand why Professor Gillingham would want to keep that component in a course like this.
Excellent lectures. Good content. Too much reading. I feel like the amount of reading could have been reduced.

The biggest strength of the course is Gillingham. He's incredibly knowledgeable, plainly puts a lot of work into prepping his lectures, uses a fascinating reading list, etc. Gillingham is one of the best professors that I've had at any level of education -- he's that good.

Ken is a great lecturer. The problem sets were very good and often times challenging. Sometimes the timing of the problem sets didn't seem consistent. Maybe just make them due biweekly or something? 

The only other constructive feedback is that the transportation and urban sections felt a bit rushed. Maybe just nix the urban part and talk through transportation a bit more in depth? The transportation policies analysis... especially in consideration with the rebound effect... was very interesting stuff.
This class could be even better than it already is if it isn't offered at 8:45 AM.
Loved the project

Strengths: very relevant information for students interested in energy. Gillingham is an engaging lecturer, and motivates students to ask questions and explore their energy interests through the semester-long group project. 

Weaknesses: there were several instances when we couldn't get through most of the lecture because the majority of class time was spent answering questions. While i see the benefits of this and support the idea of students asking questions, there were times when i felt questions got off-topic and I could have gained more by sticking to the lecture.
Grading was generous, especially on final paper; I didn't think our team deserved the grade we got.

The class touches upon a wide range of energy topics including transportation and oil & gas. The homework portion could be improved by going over those detailed economics-type questions (ex. get the graph of abatement cost, how to calculate tax revenue, etc.)
I wish I could continue with the course next semester, really great! I would love to see a full course on electricity economics

The strength is the pacing and depth. We covered so many topics without ever feeling rushed. If anything, I left feeling like the course could keep going for another semester as there was so much more to dig into.
Take it but be aware that social issues are not covered.
I highly recommend people with an interest in energy to take this class
If you are interested in energy economics, take it, but bear in mind that the class does get into the weeds a little about several energy concepts. It's helpful to have some background in economics.
Take it after having taken a few other energy classes.

If you're interested in energy issues take it! If you are an energy track student take it! If you want a good energy knowledge background, talk to Ken to make sure the level isn't too high but if you're flexible then take it.

For students with a prior background in energy, this class would be useful to learn the economics and policy component of the subject. 

For students without a prior background in energy but with an economics background, if they are keen to learn about energy, this course is fantastic! Id totally recommend taking it. Itll definitely meet their expectations!
the class is very US-centric and doesn't really cover policy objectives for the rest of the world, which can get frustrating at times
Good first class on Energy economics - probably not for advanced students that already know the field.

I recommend taking this class if you're at all interested in energy policy. Even if you're mostly interested in energy (but not necessarily policy), you'll have a better understanding of the ways policy (and economic thinking) affects energy markets.

Take this course if you're interested in renewable energy development or reducing carbon emissions through energy transitions. It is very well taught and organized. Anyone can learn a lot of useful information.
This class is wonderful but be prepared to devote a lot of time to it. There is consistent work throughout but it is well worth it!
Budget time for it!
Do the reading. Make sure to come in with a solid econ foundation, though econometrics isn't necessary.

Amazing class. You are going to learn a lot. Do the reading the best you can and ask lots of questions in class. Ken is a wealth of knowledge and can field most anything. Step up and really push yourself on the project. You have the opportunity to create something pretty cool.
The prerequisites listed on the syllabus are actually prerequisites: you're gonna need them to follow the class!
Core course for any student interested in the energy specialization.
Readings could be demanding, but there is no need to finish all the readings before class. You learn the most by reading the slides.
Do it!
Incredibly well-taught. This class is a must-take for anyone interested in Energy, Climate, DC, or how to understand policy as an intervention.
